bboxes.raw_text:
Franklin Fraziers prema-
ture death was an irreparable
loss to sociology as study in
realistic terms Of social issues.
His posthumous work on the Ne
gro church is brief but brill
liant analysis Ct the historical
origin and the present situation
of a crucially important institu-
tion Of the American Negro peo-
pie. He did not live long enough
to witness and comment upon the
recent Negro rebellion against
discrimination, segregation, un-
employment, underemployment
and poverty. But his book gives
the background necessary for
understanding why the church,
the religious leaders and the
religion itself have played such
an important role in that re-
bellion," said Gunnar Myrdal,
author of 1.-The American Dr.
lemma.


The Negro church has been at
once, as Professor Frazier sug-
gests, the most stable institution
on the Negro side Of the Amer
lean color line and the least
powerful. 1t has been an institu-
tion of accommodation and pro-
test. From that ambivalent char
acter has now emerged the emo
tional strength to fight battle
on which the future Of democracy
in America probably depends.
1.-The Negro Church in America"
must be read If the complex and
tragic circumstances of the
march of the American Negro,
out of their churches into the
streets, to demand their dignity,
is to be fully comprehended even
by readers within the Negro COM
munity itself.

NEGRO CHURCH
ANALYzED BY


FRANKLIN FRAZIER

CANTON, Miss. Negro citi-
zens of this community and Madi-
son County. by their persistence,
have demonstrated that they will
not let recalcitrant voter regis
tration clerk or police intimida-
ton keep them from attempting to
register to vote.


When the National Association
for the Advancement of Colored
People. in cooperation with other
civil rights groups, launched the
1864 voter registration drive
Friday. Feb. %, called Free
dom Day." more than 260 people
showed up at the courthouse.
Only seven we're permitted in
side, however, to make applica-
ton and to take the test.


Every day since, groups of
Negro citizens have appeared at
the registrar office to wait
patiently for their turn. In spite
of the fact that only four people
have been placed on the ballot
rolls, they continue to come.

Vote Drive
Continues

dom Day." more than 260 people
